comment._content: It is very sad, the same people who manage lands are the same people who removed a piece of their own history, and on both sides of this street, now all that is left is the building in the far distance.

comment._content: you can see why barnet wanted the clock tower located at rear of building. he wanted it to be seen from spring and bent streets. not centred .cool pic

comment.author: 51729007@N02
comment._content: I think it's interesting how these photos show that clocks were such an important aspect of the urban landscape, especially in business districts. I guess they aren't as important today since anyone can check the time on their wristwatch or iPhone, etc.. A bit of a shame really, though with my terrible eyesight they probably wouldn't be much use to me anyway!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51729007@N02] They had bells and chimes for people like you (and me)!

comment.author: 51729007@N02
comment._content: Ha ha, true beachcomberaustralia, they really do think of everything :)

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Per the various newspaper reports on the addition of the statues at the Lands Office, this pic appears to have been taken between ca. mid-late 1893 and ca. October 1901. The four lower level Bent St statues were added in 1892-1893 (l-r: Blaxland in ca. May 1893, Wentworth on 5/3/1892, Robertson in ca. September 1892, Cunningham in ca. January 1893). Of the two middle level Bent St statues, Lawson appears to have been added during the second half of 1893...one newspaper item indicates he was in place by January 1894. Farnell was a later addition (some time between June 1901- and October 1903). In this pic we can see two of the first level statues (Blaxland and Wentworth), and one of the middle level statues (ie. Lawson)...and the vacant niche beside Lawson, later occupied by Farnell. The four Gresham St statues occupy lower level niches. Deniehy appears to have been the first added (ca. October 1901). Grey appears to have been added at about the same time. I have yet to find dates for Parkes and Martin...they appear to have been added in 1902. In this pic we can see the vacant niches later occupied by Deniehy and Martin. See my comments re the Lands Office statues here - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5401920179/
